text:
HEIDI: Our webinar topic
today is AI in the workplace, rethinking skill development.

It is my pleasure to introduce
our guest speaker, Arvind Karunakaran.

Arvind is an assistant
professor at Stanford University in the Department of Management
Science and Engineering.

He is a core faculty member of
the Center for Work, Technology and Organization, Stanford
Technology Ventures Program,

and a faculty affiliate of the
Stanford Institute for Human Centered Artificial Intelligence
and the Digital Economy Lab.

His research draws on
organizational theory and the sociology of
work, examining authority

and accountability
in the workplace, especially in the context
of technological change.

Arvind also teaches in the
Stanford Online Digital Transformation Program. He teaches a course called
XDGT 130, change management,

reskilling in the age
of analytics and AI. Arvind, welcome and thank
you for being with us today.

ARVIND KARUNAKARAN: Thank you. Thank you, Heidi. And thank you, everybody,
too, for joining.

Super excited to get
this webinar started. So as Heidi mentioned, my
name is Arvind Karunakaran.

I'm a faculty here at Stanford. Prior to joining, I did
my PhD at MIT Sloan.

I worked in the tech
industry before that for a number of years in
several different roles.

Broadly, my research
focuses on how technology, especially emerging
technologies such as AI

impacts the structure of work,
how does that impact especially skills and skill
development, and more

broader implications for the
organization and strategy. So that's what we're going
to talk about today, zooming

on one specific topic,
especially with respect to AI and GenAI and how
is that impacting skills

and what could we
as individuals, but also as managers
supervising many people on how

could we facilitate
skill development. So that's going to
be the overall focus.

As Heidi mentioned,
please use the Q&A box if you have any
questions throughout.

We will also handle questions
at the end of the presentation. But if you have any
questions in between,

please feel free to share them. But let me get started with
some kind of a warm up activity.

And please, again, use the
Q&A box to put your responses for this question.

So the warm up question
I'm going to ask is the following--
of course, there have been like many types
of technologies the past two

decades, especially
introduced into the workplace. You could think
about analytics, you

could think about ERP systems
and CRM systems and so forth. So the question I wanted to
ask is is there anything at all

unique that you think
about AI and specifically Generative AI like ChatGPT
and DALL-E and platforms

like that as compared to the
other types of technologies that you have been exposed to,
all the way from your ERP CRM

systems to something like
Zoom, remote work platforms. So could you think of
something that is particularly

unique about GenAI. Please, again, use the Q&A
box to put in your responses

or just think for yourself. Is there something fundamentally
unique about GenAI.

So let's take like
maybe 30 seconds to think through something
that is particularly unique.

Thinks for you. That's interesting. Yes. But something that is like
particularly unique as

compared to, say,
analytics, as compared to other types of technologies
you have been exposed.
To speed of change, for sure.

Multi usage, unlimited
possibilities. Yes Yeah, there's also
questions about dependability.

Yeah. Speed of delivery of
information, for sure.
Yeah.

Can create content
versus being fed data. That's important.

But I would urge
you to think about if there's something that is
particularly unique that most

of the technologies could
not quite replicate, not

just in terms of what
it is capable of, but also in terms of something
that is even more deeper.

Yeah, vertical
specific use cases. Yeah, we're getting a lot of
very interesting responses.

All of them, super insightful. But from my perspective, what is
particularly unique about GenAI

as compared to other
types of technologies that we have seen in the past
two decades is the following--

other technologies,
as I mentioned, your remote work tools like
Zoom or your enterprise resource

planning or CRM systems,
all of these technologies have features and
functionalities.

There are some set of pre-built
features and functionalities that you could train your
employees and your managers

on how to use those features
and functionalities. You could have
training programs,

the vendors could provide
videos, you could watch them, you could actually
use those technologies

and learn what those features
and functionalities are. But if you think about
Generative AI specifically,

it's not that there are
some pre-built features and functionalities per se. I mean, apart from your
ability to type in prompts,

there are no specific pre-built
features functionalities. Instead, these
functionalities gets

discovered as people use it as
a part of their everyday work. I mean, if you think about
how you use ChatGPT or any

of these GenAI LLM
technologies, it's not that they come in with OK,
you could use it for x, y, z.

Only when you use
it and experiment as a part of your
everyday work, you discover what it is good for,
what it is not really great for.

And in the process, you try to
adapt and embed the technology as a part of your everyday work.

So that's, in my
mind, something that is particularly unique with
respect to GenAI as opposed

to other technologies. No pre-built features
functionalities per se. It gets discovered as
people use and experiment

as a part of their everyday work
in a very trial and error basis.

So that has a lot
of implications. If you think about the topic
for today about skills and skill

development, the broader
issue is the following-- if the value of GenAI gets
discovered only when people use

it and experiment in
trial and error fashion, discover what it is good for,
not good for, then that means

that people should indeed-- they need to experiment
on an everyday basis. But why would they
experiment if you

are an employee of a company? Why would you experiment if you
don't really see a value in it

or if you see that
the technology itself could be a threat for your
own job, your expertise

in the long run, or if you see
that there are a lot of issues? Some of you mentioned
about hallucinations.

So therefore, it is
non-obvious that people would experiment and use the
technology on an everyday basis.

And because there are
no pre-built features and functionalities,
it's also very difficult for organizations,
if you are a manager,

to train your workforce
to your employees to use these technologies. You can't force them.

You can have some training
programs on how to use prompts better, different
types of prompting

tactics and strategies. But beyond that, it is actually
up to the people on the ground

to discover. So that's one issue that we have
been trying to grapple with.

A lot of organizations
are investing money to get an enterprise wide
license for different types

of GenAI technologies
from ChatGPT to DALL-E and many other platforms. But there have been issues with
respect to adoption of use.

People either they are
not using it regularly, or even if they're
using it, it is not

facilitating what we call a
culture of experimentation and knowledge
sharing among people.

They are not trying to explore
the different possibilities of GenAI, which in turn has
some downstream impact, which

I'll talk about. So that's one. The second important
thing is, how do you go about embedding AI as a
part of people's everyday work.

This again, cannot really be
very much of a top down enforced process.

It needs to be an
emergent bottom up process as people discover
what the technology is good for their work to
accomplish their work.

So that's the second thing
that we will briefly touch on and the implications
it has for skills.

And finally, if
you are a manager, the question people ask
is, OK, we have invested so much in this technology.

What is the ROI. Typically, that leads to a lot
of issues around measurement.

And my argument here
is that we are actually trying to measure the wrong
things in terms of productivity gains as opposed to
trying to measure

other important things such as
skills and skill development. And we will talk about
some of those issues too,

as a part of the webinar. So that's the first category
of issues to consider.

Adoption and usage,
specifically how to facilitate a culture
of experimentation so that people actually
learn to use the technology,

but also develop new
skills in the process. So that's the key takeaway.

The second is, how do you
structure these initiatives. If you are not just an employee,
but if you are managing

set of people, how do
you go about structuring these initiatives? Should you have a
center of excellence,

should you do it in a
very decentralized manner, or should you centralize
it, have best practices?

It's actually non-obvious
if you think about it, because there are
different trade offs in each of these choices.

And we'll talk about that too. And finally, the last
issue to consider is, like we briefly
touched upon,

is on skill development
and productivity. There are two issues
to consider here.

One is a lot of places,
individual employees

are experimenting with GenAI. If you are a graphic
designer, if you're a programmer using Copilot or
any one of these technologies,

people are using it. But again, there is very
less incentive for them to report that
they are using it. You could basically be
a lot more productive,

but then you don't need
to report that you're being that productive. You could do other things, you
could take on a second job,

or you could just like
chill out or watch Netflix when you are working. So that's another issue--

how do we capture the
individual gains in productivity at the organizational
level, what

are the types of incentives,
other types of programs should put in place so
that actually people

share that they're
using GenAI and there is some form of
cumulative knowledge across the organization
that gets shared.

So that's one issue is
leakage from individual to organizational productivity,
how do we manage that.

That's one issue. But the more substantive issue
is people, especially managers,

tend to conflate gains in
productivity to gains in skills.

Just because you're more
productive doing the same task much faster does not
necessarily mean that you're

learning or gaining new skills. In fact, you might lose skills. You're overdependent
on this technology.

You lose skills or you're
not learning anything new. And in the long run,
you get left out

in the process as an individual. So we will talk about
that conundrum, too. So how do you facilitate
skill development

as an individual
employee level where you're doing more
complex tasks, not just the same tasks much more
faster, and in the process

you're also more productive. The productivity gain is
almost like a byproduct because you're gaining new
skills in the process, not

the vice versa. So these are the things that
we're going to talk about today. How do you make sure that
employees are gaining new skills

in the process, performing
more complex tasks as opposed to just doing the same task much
faster, which over time actually

makes them lose skills? So how do we avoid those traps? So these are the
things that we're

going to talk about, mainly
focused on angular on skills and organizational change.

So let's get started. If you are actually interested
in this topic on skills and skill development, there's
a very good book, a recent book

that just came out by Matt Beane
called the Skill Code, where he goes a lot of depth
talking about this trade off

between productivity
and skills and how do you make sure employees
learn new skills in the process.

So I would highly recommend if
you're interested in this topic to learn more.

So the angle that we're going to
deal with on skill development

is a simple framework
that we have developed, what we call the three
lenses framework.

And as the name
suggests, the lens is way of looking at the world. It's not that one lens is right
or this is wrong or better.

It's just different ways
of looking at the world. So the three lenses
are what we call

the first lens is a
strategic design lens, the second lens is a
power and political lens,

and the third lens
is a cultural lens. And each lens have some basic
assumptions and basic sort

of strategies, but
it has implications both for change at the
organizational level,

but also change at the
individual level in terms of skills and
learning new skills. So let me briefly
walk through that.

And then I will actually
give some concrete examples based on actual GenAI
use in a company

and what type of challenges
they face with respect to skill development in their employees.

And then we will wrap
it up after that. So that's going to be the plan
for the rest of the webinar. So let me walk through
briefly about the three lenses

framework. The first lens is called
the strategic design lens. So from this lens,
the assumption

is that organizations
are like machines. It's an information
processing machine.

So therefore, you have to
optimize an organization properly so that
information flows better

between different
parts and people are able to basically
understand the dependencies across different
parts of the machine.

So things such as how do you
structure AI initiatives, should you keep it
centralized, decentralized,

how more of a network
of excellence model-- all of that would
fall under this lens, the various trade offs involved.

could develop skills. The second lens is the
power and political lens.

And this lens is-- according to this
lens, the assumption is that organizations
are like contests.

People are contesting for
resources, for power and status, many other things.

It's not just like a
information processing machine. It is actually a status contest,
a contest for resources.

So therefore, here, issues
around jurisdiction and turf becomes all the more important.

And when I get to the
case, these issues will become a lot more clear. With respect to AI
and skill development,

the way people
will develop skills through using AI is
not just learning more about the technology
itself, more about ChatGPT,

but also using the
technology to do more complex tasks and
complex types of activities.

But if you think about it in an
actual organizational context, if you do more complex
tasks, oftentimes than not,

you're stepping into
someone else's shoes, someone else who's already
doing that complex work.

So how do you manage those
dynamics, those power political dynamics, issues
around jurisdiction and turf

wars which, again, has a lot
of implications for skills and skill development. We'll talk about that, too.

And finally, the cultural lens. According to this
lens, organizations are viewed as institutions.

The lot about
meaning and the type of practices, the
informal norms, the particular
organization or even

a division within an
organization shares, which in turn facilitates
certain types of climate

inside that division or
inside that organization, which in turn allows
people to experiment more.

There's a lot more tolerance for
failure versus a lot more strict about not making mistakes.

So all of these, again,
matter with respect to using GenAI to
learn new skills.

So that's the three lenses
framework we're going to use. But to make this a
lot more concrete,

we're going to actually
look at a real case study of a company using GenAI.

Over the past two
years, this company adopted the Generative AI. This is a corporate law firm
that does patent and IP law.

They adopted this
technology even before ChatGPT was released. This was a very vertical,
specific, large language

model for the legal industry
mainly used by paralegals.

So I will use this case to
walk through what we found and some of the trade offs
in the different lenses

that I talked about with respect
to skill development and stuff like that. And then we'll have some broader
takeaways from this case--

what does it mean for you
either as an individual employee or as a manager, managing
others with respect

to how do you
develop skills, how do you reskill your
workforce in the wake of AI.

So let's jump in. So the first choice, this
organization, as I mentioned,

it's a corporate law firm that
does patent IP related law. The first choice this
organization faced was they

realized the founders
and the partners realized that AI
is coming, GenAI

is coming to disrupt
their industry. And especially so because
if you know anything about corporate law firms,
they are a very document text

heavy industry. They generate a lot
of documents and text and contracts and
non-disclosure agreements.

They write complex
contracts for their clients. Bulk of what they
do is around that. So they know that the GenAI
and large language models

are coming. So they were ahead
of time adopting this vertical specific
LLM for legal services.

So the choice they
face was how do we go about implementing and
introducing this initiative

different trade offs. From a strategic
design perspective, they could have a more
centralized functional

model where they have some kind
of an analytics and AI group that is in charge
of this initiative,

in charge of adopting
this technology, and scaling it up
across the organization.

Or they could do a more
decentralized model. Each business unit or each
division within the law firm

could go about implementing AI
and associated technologies. That's the second choice.

We had the divisional managers
have a lot more leeway. And finally, they could have a
more of a consulting model where

they could bring
in either outside experts or some kind of a
specialized group focused

on GenAI. They would be in
charge of finding out what the best practices are,
implementing them, training

the workforce, training the
attorneys and the paralegals who work for this organization.

Different trade offs
in each of the models as you could think about. The functional model, you
will have best practices.

It's a little bit more to
have consistent practices across the organization,
but you really

don't know what is the best use
case for one particular division versus others. You really don't know what
exactly one type of paralegal

have other types of
trade offs involved. Here, you will not
have uniformity,

you might not even
have consistency on how the technology
is used, but there is a lot more discretion
at the division level.

They can decide how to roll
this technology, what type of incentives to
set, and so forth. So trade offs in each of this.

But this organization decided
that given each business unit have different
sets of demands,

they decided to go for
a decentralized model. In other words, each
division manager

would have discretion on
how to go about introducing

this technology called the law
board-- again, a large language model trained on the
legal services industry.

So it's a very
decentralized model. The division managers
have a lot of leeway. So that's the starting point.

So what happened
afterwards once they decided that we will allow the
division managers to implement,

roll out GenAI and
make sure that people are trained on how to use
the technology and so forth?

So what we observed,
we basically followed two divisions. Let's call them division
A and B of this company,

a legal course, a pseudonym. And we track them
for many years,

a couple of years on how the
technology is getting used. And these divisions are pretty
similar in a lot of dimensions.

They did similar
types of patent law, the paralegals were
trained similarly, the backgrounds
were quite similar.

What we found was the
following-- again, remember, the
earlier I mentioned about the importance of ongoing
usage and experimentation

to even discover the value
of these technologies, what it is good for, what
it is not good for.

So we basically tracked is their
substantive variation in usage across the paralegals
who are the main users

of this technology across
this division A and B. And we did find quite
substantive difference.

In terms of just raw usage,
we found the paralegals in division A using it
a lot more, 58% more.

But more than that usage,
we found experimentation was quite important.

We found the paralegals
in division A were experimenting
with the technology a lot more, a lot more
than the paralegals

in the other division. And we were like, what is
going on, why do we see this. And by experimentation
here, I mean

they were using a lot more-- discovering a lot more
features and functionalities that even the designers of this
technology didn't envision.

For instance, some
of the paralegals were using this law board to
basically do case analysis

to look at prior case
histories and stuff like that to do legal research. And that was not originally this
technology was designed for.

This technology
was mainly designed to create contracts
and NDAs, foster it,

to combine different
legal classes and create a complex contract
or a non-disclosure agreement

much faster. That was the original use case. But through experimentation,
the paralegals in division A

found that no, we can actually
use it for other things, for legal research,
for many other purposes

than just creating
contracts and NDAs. So that was great. But that was not happening
so much in division

B. The paralegals were actually
not experimenting or discovering new use cases for
this technology.

Finally, there's also
less knowledge sharing on the paralegals in
division B as compared

to division A. For instance,
the paralegals would say, if I did this type of prompting,
it is not working quite well.

It is hallucinating. And they were trying to reverse
engineer why it is happening, what type of prompts to avoid,
what type of chain of thought

prompts that they should
give, stuff like that. A lot more of that happening in
division A versus division B.

So that was a basic finding
that we started with. Why do we see substantive
variation in both usage,

but more importantly in
experimentation and knowledge sharing, which are some
implications of what

kind of skills the paralegals
developed in the process, which I'll get to. But I want to ask you,
think for a few minutes

on why this is
happening, why do we see the substantive variation,
what do you think

is some of the causes are. Again, use the Q&A. Why do
you see that division A,

the paralegals are using it,
experimenting a lot more, sharing their knowledge
with each other as compared

to the paralegals in division B? Again, use the Q&A to
jot down any thought that comes to your mind.

Do you think it's because
the incentives are different, do you think it's because
the culture is different? Whatever comes to your mind,
please put them in the Q&A.

And then we can have a
conversation about it.

Yeah, so do you think that
the paralegals in division A are trained differently or--

think about what are
the potential reasons. And then I'll talk about what
are the actual reasons on why we

see the substantive variation. Competition, some psychological
safety to experiment--

that's great. That's one of the
reasons, definitely. Fear of losing skills
job by technology.

Great. But again, ask why is it
that one set of paralegals might have had that fear
over the other side.

It's, again, the same
company, they paid same, the incentives are the
same, the culture is also

more or less the same too. So ask about what
is causing this. Staff in division
A is the younger.

Not necessarily. We looked at the age and
the experience levels of the paralegals
across the divisions

are more or less the same. Leadership difference. Great. But it could be a
bit more specific

on what that would entail. So these are all great answers. So let me briefly walk
through what happened.

Let's start with
the division where things were not going great. The division B where there
was less usage, basically

less experimentation,
less knowledge sharing. What happened was the
division-- again, remember,

this organization chose to
use a very decentralized model to introduce and scale up GenAI.

So the division managers had
a lot of discretion and leeway and how they went about
positioning this technology

and introducing it, what
incentives and other things they had in place. So the managers in division B,
they introduced this technology

as a generic productivity
improvement tool. That's the framing they
use when they introduced it in the meetings and the
emails they sent out

saying, use this
LawBot, this GenAI technology to do your
contracts and NDA's faster.

So that's the framing, that's
the positioning they use, a productivity enhancement tool. Very less focus on skills
or skill development or job

enrichment. Essentially, what is in
it for the paralegals if they are a lot
more productive? Very less focus on that.

And also, lack of
credible commitment from the managers on
what opportunities for the paralegals, what do
they have to perform new tasks,

new skills. So this was the starting point
which created a set of dynamics that we tracked through
interviews, observations,

and some experiments we did. So because the managers
in this division said,

this LawBot could be viewed as
a productivity improvement tool. The paralegals actually
asked the question, OK,

what if we are more
productive today, and what if we are more
productive two months from now, what is going to
happen to us both individually,

but also as a group. Say, six months or one
year or two years from now, just because we are
more productive,

are we shooting
ourselves on the foot and replacing ourselves
in the process.

So they viewed LawBot
this GenAI technology as a threat that
devalues their expertise.

It might be great in
improving their productivity, but it is not doing
anything for them.

What is in it for them in
terms of new skill development or basically some signal
about career mobility?

So that was clearly lacking. So that created some
kind of a vicious cycle. The paralegals first thought
of this technology as a threat

to their expertise that
devalues their expertise. And sometimes, they
even worried they

might get consolidated into
some kind of a shared service. They lose power in
the process, which

in turn led to lack of trust
in the technology itself. But it is not that
they were not using it.

They were still trying
to use it here and there. But the minute they
used it and they found

some problems, if the technology
throws up a wrong legal clause

or if it hallucinates and makes
up a clause that doesn't even exist, they anchored
and overemphasis

on those negative
experiences saying, see, I can't trust this
technology because it is just

throwing up some garbage. And they anchored
around that instead of trying to experiment
and work around and see

what it is good for. And because they anchored around
those negative experiences,

it led to further lack of
trust, further lack of usage and experimentation. So that led to
this vicious cycle.

So not only they were able
to discover new use cases, but they were not also
able to do new tasks

and expand their jurisdiction
as opposed to the paralegals in other division
that we'll talk about.

And in the process, there was
very less opportunities for them to learn new skills. So therefore, they thought
the technology is not really

helping them anyway. So that's what happened,
paralegals in this division, as one of them said,
I don't like LawBot,

I don't find it useful, it's a
pain, it has a lot of issues. And we, the paralegals
in division B,

don't trust it enough
to use it every day. So there's one thing that I want
to highlight, this paradox--

you will trust it
if you use it more and experiment and try to
understand its strengths

and limitations. But you will not do it if you
find it's almost feel threatened by experimenting.

So that's what happened
in this division. There's this psychologically--
they felt unsafe to experiment,

but also they felt there's
very less in it for them in terms of learning new
skills and career mobility

through using this technology. Rather, they felt it's
almost like a threat to their expertise. So that's what
happened in division B.

Let's get to what
happened in division A. And again, these two divisions
are in different buildings. So we didn't observe the
paralegals talking to each other

that much. So maybe if they did, that
could have changed the dynamics. I'm not sure.

But what happened in division A? Here again, the managers of this
division had a lot of discretion

on how to introduce
this technology. So here, the managers,
again, happenstance.

They did not plan explicitly
on how to introduce it. But the way they
positioned this technology

was less of a productivity
improvement tool. They did not use
things such as just use it to do your
contracts and NDAs faster,

but rather they use more
of a skill development type of framing. Use this technology to, one,
do the tasks that you always

wanted to do, complex
tasks, make room to do those tasks faster.

So that skill development or
job enrichment type of framing had a lot of positives
downstream effects,

which we will talk about. So what happened first? The way they framed
it was, as I said, first they said what
else do you want

to be involved in as a
paralegal, what are the tasks or activities that
you wanted to do, could you find this slack
time to do that in addition

to what you're already doing. So the paralegals in
this organization, a lot of their time goes in
creating these complex contracts

and NDAs, but a lot of
them also actually hated doing those tasks. They felt that that is
not what really they

are trained for or capable of. They could do a lot more complex
tasks such as legal research and stuff like that.

So therefore,
these managers also said maybe start using this
technology, this LawBot

to do the tasks that
you hate to do faster, so to do the contracts
and NDAs faster.

But that's not all
there is to it. You do it faster
so that you could do other more complex tasks
that you always wanted to do,

love to do because
you're learning new things in the process. So let me walk through what
that specifically meant.

What that meant was
that the paralegals like to do legal research. They wanted to be part of
the legal strategy meetings

and help out the attorneys. But they never had the time to
do it because most of their time

went into creating these
complex contracts, NDAs. So this positioning
was essentially saying,

use the LawBot to basically
do that boring task or tasks that you had to do faster
so that-- and this is

the important part-- so that
you could do more complex tasks that you like to do. And in the process,
you develop new skills.

So that created a lot of
positive spillovers, which we will briefly talk about.

But in addition to
that, these managers also, they credibly
committed on their promise.

They said that use this tool to
do more complex tasks that you always wanted and loved
to do like legal research.

So to do that, they
gave slack time. They're to explore this tool
to basically use the LawBot,

experiment with it, have these
knowledge sharing sessions. They gave training
and mentorship, they basically matched a
senior paralegal with a junior.

And it's actually
the junior paralegals taught the seniors on how to
use these the LawBot better.

They did a lot of other
things beyond just saying use the technology that
in turn facilitated a more

positive or a virtuous cycle. Again, here too, It's not
that the paralegals initially,

when the managers introduced the
technology, that they were all very kumbaya about this. They were not all
super enthusiastic.

They were initially
quite skeptical, saying, OK, yet another
technology that we should use.

So they were quite
skeptical initially. But this framing around
you are able to learn new skills, do more complex
tasks in the process,

in addition to a
bunch of other things, the continued commitment
towards training and mentorship and basically learning more
complex tasks and skills--

that motivated them to at
least try out the technology. So as you see in this figure,
they took this leap of faith

to experiment and use GenAI. Sometimes it works,
sometimes it did not. So they had both negative,
positive, and some ambivalent

experiences. But because they felt that
there was something in it for them in terms of
learning new skills

and doing more complex tasks,
they persisted with it. They did more, continued to
use and experiment and share

their knowledge with each other
what is working, what is not, what prompts to use, what
to avoid, stuff like that.

And in that process, they
were able to understand the strengths of the
technology also better, which

led to more usage, more
experimentation, more knowledge sharing. And even more importantly,
through this process,

they not only learned about
the technology better, what it is good for, not
good for, what to avoid,

but also they were able
to do more complex tasks that they didn't do. As I said, legal research,
being part of client strategy

meetings, taking notes,
bunch of other things that they were not doing before. And this process together,
using the technology

to do more complex
tasks, and in the process of doing complex tasks, you
learn the technology better.

That cycle is the main thing
that I wanted to communicate. That's the way that
people learn new skills

and also learn to use the
technology GenAI much better in the process,
because it is based

on not some hypothetical
task, but actual tasks that they do as a part
of their everyday work.

So this division,
as you could see, the paralegals were like,
I wanted to find out what tasks I could do faster.

We paralegals hate doing NDAs,

And we would love to be part

do NDAs and contracts faster

and client interfacing
and doing legal research and all other complex tasks
that they wanted to do.

So that's the first
set of findings where you see one
set of paralegals able to learn new skills in the
process of using the technology

and performing
more complex tasks. But that's not the
end of the story. There is a positive
spillover that happened.

Because the paralegals
in this division were able to do
more complex tasks, it had a spillover to
other types of roles.

The legal, secretaries,
or admin assistants started doing bit more
complex tasks in the process

than what they used to do. Likewise, the clerks
and the summer attorneys started doing more
complex tasks using

this technology
and, in the process, learning the technology
better, but also performing more additional
tasks and learning

new skills in the process. So that's the positive part. But that's not the
end of the story.

Here is where the power and
politics comes into the picture.

Now the paralegals are doing
a lot more complex tasks like legal research,
interfacing with clients,

being part of legal
strategy meetings, at least being on the background, taking
notes, and stuff like that.

The junior attorneys
in this division, division A-- and these
are your second year,

third year associates
straight out of law school-- they felt threatened
by the paralegals

being part of doing all this
legal research and stuff. So they were pushing back,

don't intrude my turf almost. So the paralegals-- this is
a junior attorney saying,

the paralegals are not

but screw up their main task

and make mistakes that

blah, blah, blah. So essentially, they're saying
that stick toward your lane, don't come to--

don't intrude my turf,
which if you think about it, it's not a very productive way. It's not that the
junior attorneys

have only certain
types of tasks to do. It's not a zero sum game. They could do a lot
more complex tasks

than doing basic legal research. So therefore, here, this is what
we call a lump of task fallacy.

It's almost a zero
sum mindset where people think that these
are the tasks that we have under our jurisdiction
and nobody else

should come and do it. And in the process, they are
limited in what type of skills they develop and so forth.

So as the manager, they
have to basically get

rid of this lump
of task fallacy. They have to intervene. And the managers
of this division

intervened to actually
redesign the role of the junior attorneys,

more complex legal research

or other things that
you're not doing. And in the process,
learn the technology,

but also learn new skills
and perform new tasks. So they had to redesign the

too, in the process. So the upshot here with
this is that, basically,

the junior attorneys in
this organization thought, these are all the tasks
that they could do,

but they have to redesign
the role of multiple people in the organization
if at all you're

going to derive some value
from technology such as GenAI. If we only focused
on the paralegals

and ignored the
others, you're going to get some pushback
from more senior roles

such as the attorneys. So if you are a
manager, think not just about redesigning
one role at a time,

but think about
map multiple roles and what the dependencies are
and try to redesign multiple

of them by giving
them opportunities to learn new skills to
perform more complex tasks. In the process, you would see
a more positive spillover.

So the final thing that happened
here in this organization is now that the
paralegals are doing

a lot of legal related
stuff like legal research, but also some business

like interfacing with clients,

So basically, the organizational

because people are
using this technology and developing new
skills in the process. So therefore, the broader
message I wanted to leave

is that we have to think more
organizationally if you're thinking about using
GenAI to learn new skills.

It is not just about
one individual. You have to rethink the whole
organizational structure

as a system. And only then we will
see positive impact in terms of both
productivity gains,

but also more importantly,
in terms of skills and skill development. So that's basically
the broader takeaway

is, one, the role
of experimentation. That's super important,
especially in the case of GenAI.

And you have to facilitate a
culture of experimentation. Only then you would see
what this technology

could be good for. And the way to do it is to
incentivize people saying,

you are able to learn new skills
and perform more complex tasks in the process. If you just use the language
around productivity,

perhaps that is not
going to take you far. People interpret productivity
and productivity improvement

a threat to their job,

rather using it as a
part of skill development and basically continue
your commitment

towards that as a manager,

helpful and important

to leverage the benefits

about not just redesigning

together to avoid all
